Title: the cooperkripke inversion

Leonard: Sheldon, your food’s getting cold.
Oh, this is neat. Think about all the action figures we’ve bought over the years. It would be kind of cool to have ones that look like us. Don’t you think?
Yeah, so, I’m out.
You get that these are personalised action figures.
Yep.
Hmm. Kind of a strange place to put a picture of you and Bernadette.
A thousand dollars on action figures? How can you afford that?
Maybe it’s a shipping problem.
Yeah. Maybe Wesley Snipes and Toucan Sam just got action figures that look like you guys.
Aw, and my girlfriend wouldn’t let me get one. Look at my face. Do I look smug? I feel smug.
Well, sometimes there’s a secret ending, like in The Avengers.
They could show bloopers. Oh, no.
That is Sheldon’s “I’m unhappy and about to destroy the planet” music. Come on, let’s just go to your place.
Shouldn’t we talk to him? Have you learned nothing in six years?
Want me to make you some tea?
So, cocoa?
Oh, teacher! Me! Me!
Oh, no, no, no, I know this. Uh, hot apple cider with cinnamon sticks?
Come on, Sheldon, we’re going to be late.
You’re not sick. You just don’t want to face Kripke.
What did you do, put this in your tea?
Sheldon, Kripke’s not smarter than you. You just got stuck on a wrong path. Happened to Einstein. He got stuck on the unified field theory for decades.
Sheldon Lee Cooper, I do not have time for this nonsense. Now, go put your clothes on, get in the car, and lets go to work.
How did I do that? I got to remember how I did that.
Is my coitus whimsically inventive?
I know you’re joking, but I’d be okay with that.
We don’t ask Sheldon things like that.
All right, we’re down the rabbit hole. What are you doing?
Now you know how I feel when I have to put it on you.
Ow!
Sheldon: I’ll eat later. Right now, I’m suckling at the informative bosom of mother physics.
Would it come with Kung-Fu grip?
Don’t waste my time.

A hush falls over the crowd as Cooper studies the board. He makes his move. He’s dividing both sides by I. He’s adding back the coefficient. He has a value for P. He’s plugging that back in. He takes the derivative, and he solves the equation. The crowd goes wild. Nobel! Nobel!
Nobel. Kripke. Don’t look at my board.
That’s a drawing of a really cool train. Don’t look at that, either. What do you want?
So they asked you to pack up your things and ship out. That’s hard cheese, Barry. You’re one of the good ones.
That’s ridiculous. I am one of the great minds of our generation. I work on a level so rarified you couldn’t even imagine it. I said stop looking at my cool train!
There is ominous music playing, and there is an afghan over my head. I don’t know where you’re from, but where I’m from, that means I’m not doing okay.
Tea is for when I’m upset. I’m not upset. The university’s forcing me to work with Kripke. I’m outraged.
Yes, cocoa. Do you have any idea what it’s like to be paired with someone who’s so incredibly annoying?
See, I did all this great work, and now he’s just going to come along and ruin it. I am angrier than ever and filled with despair.
Yes, hot apple cider with cinnamon sticks!
And yet, now you’re in my office. Point, Cooper. Welcome to the Thunderdome, Kripke.
Why don’t you show me yours first.
How do I know you’re not going to take my ideas and publish them as your own?
Because I’m not interested in getting published in Mad magazine. Zingers fly fast in the Thunderdome, Barry.
Fine.
And I am sure it’s still more valuable than whatever’s in here.
Very well.
Fine.
I’m fine.
Yes.
I read his research, and, it’s leaps and bounds ahead of mine. Which means the mommy of the smartest physicist at the university is not my mommy as I had thought. It’s his mommy.
What do we have to lose?
I feel like I’m being strangled by a boa constrictor. Why’d you stop?
I can’t go in today. I’m sick.
No, look.
See?
Oh, dear. Now I’m not even smarter than you.
Oh, don’t play the Einstein card. His great breakthroughs happened when no one knew anything. So everything was a great breakthrough.
All right, geez. What a grouch.
I know. Go ahead, mock me. Just use small words so I understand.
We do?
So?
Yes. That is the reason. My work is suffering because of all the laid I’m getting.
What can I say, you know? She enjoys my genitals. I am giving them to her on a nightly basis.
I’ll do what I can. But it’s not going to be easy, because when I’m with Amy and our bathing suit areas mush together, boy howdy, is it magic
Because the truth made me look bad, whereas a ridiculous bald-faced lie makes me look good. Anyway, if Kripke asks, tell him my coitus with Amy is frequent, intense and whimsically inventive.
Of course.
That’s awfully personal.
Well, word around the university is I’m giving her sex organs a proper jostling.
Well, first of all, I’m quite fond of Amy.

Penny, all my life, I have been uncomfortable with the sort of physical contact that comes easily to others, hand-shaking, hugging, prostate exams. But I’m working on it, you know? Just recently, I had to put VapoRub on Amy’s chest. A year ago, that would have been unthinkable.
It’s a possibility.
Fine.
Well, the equation balances, but it’s certainly not elegant.
Yes.
No, I gave it to her well. Now, over here, I was thinking the turbulence could be reduced if we just put…
I didn’t notice.
I was too busy squishing all the desirable parts of her body.
Can we get back to work?
Toys? I do have a model rocket next to my bed.
Penny: It’s hot when Sheldon talks dirty.
Yeah, if that’s your idea of what’s cool, you should get one.
Honey, if you want one, just get one.
I hate it when you make me sit through all the credits.
Yeah, but I don’t think that’s going to happen in a documentary about the Holocaust.
Well, wait, if he’s unhappy,shouldn’t we talk to him?
What beverage do you make for that?
All right, I don’t understand. Why didn’t you just tell Kripke the truth?
That is what I write on the bathroom walls. For a whimsically inventive time, call Leonard Hofstadter.
Yeah. Sheldon, can I ask you a question?
You ever going to sleep with Amy?
Maybe you don’t, I do. What’s the deal?
All right, come on, be serious. Look, you guys have been going out a long time. She would clearly like to have a physical relationship with you, so what are you doing?
Okay. Hang on. Are you saying someday you and Amy might actually get physical?
Raj: So, I found this Web site where you send them pictures, they sculpt your head and make an action figure out of you. How awesome is that?
Yeah, you can pick your wardrobe. You can even choose your accessories.
What do you think, Sheldon? Want an action figure that looks just like you?
No.
They’re here. Our action figures have arrived. This is the best five hundred dollars I’ve ever spent.
Say hello to an exact scale model of me. Oh, I’m not dark chocolate. I’m melt-in-your-mouth caramel.
This sucks.
You! Always bet on black.
It’s only a waste of money if we don’t play with them. (As doll) He’s right, dawg.
You know, there is a way we can get action figures to look exactly like us.
Two words, 3-D printer. Wait, maybe it’s three words. No, hang on. Okay, one word, a letter and a number and maybe a hyphen. 3-D printer.
Of course you have. They’re an engineer’s dream. Anything you can design, a 3-D printer can make out of plastic.
Oh, come on. You deserve one. You’ve worked hard to find a woman who makes a lot of money.
Oh, true. They’re practically giving them away. You know, in exchange for money.
Not to mention Malibu Koothrappali and his totally bitchin’ dream house.
Really, smart guy? Where’s he supposed to park his sweet little Corvette?
I think this thing was made in China.
Ooh, I, I think it’s done. Oh, it worked. We printed a whistle.
And we made it in only three hours. Sounds just like store-bought.
Oh, I wish I was in better shape.
Oh, okay, great. Now I can look like Val Kilmer as Batman instead of Val Kilmer as he looks today.
Are you sure you want to do this? Give up your half of the 3-D printer?
Wow, that’s harsh.
Aren’t you gonna eat lunch?
Howard: Let me see.
Leonard, you can get a little asthma inhaler.
You’re still out, right?
Well, I wanted everybody to know I love my wife. And nobody to know I forgot to turn off the laser.
Easy. His family’s loaded, and Bernadette has a great job. My wife came with both fun bags and money bags.
Oh, man. Look at my nose.
What?
I can’t believe I wasted all that money.
Get that waste of money out of my face.
Please, I’m working.
Oh, yeah? How’s that?
I have always wanted a 3-D printer.
Yeah, but they’re so expensive.
Well, the prices have been coming down.
And we can make stuff we need for work with it. Prototypes of my CAD/CAM designs, specialized tools…
We don’t need Malibu Koothrappali’s dream house.
Do you realize, by owning a 3-D printer, we are reclaiming the manufacturing process and taking jobs back from sweatshops in China?
Eh, what can you do?
Amazing. You realize these things go for 25 cents a pop at a party store.
Okay, give me a superhero pose, and I will scan you into the computer for your action figure.
Stop holding your stomach in. I’ll give you a six-pack with the computer.
All right, you can suck it in a little bit.
Oh, good, you’re home. Got a little surprise for you.
Say hello to my little friend.
I know, right? And, thanks to photographs and a little 3-D modeling, here comes the bride.
I thought you might.
Didn’t cost a thing. I made them myself.
Koothrappali and I bought a used 3-D printer for $5,000.
Not just for a couple of dolls. For as many dolls as we want. And whistles.
It’s kind of dawning on me now.
What are you talking about? We make plenty of money.
Yes, but we’re married now. That means, when you get sick, I take care of you. And when you make a bunch of money, I get to buy stuff. Sorry if you don’t like it, but that’s how love works.
Yes. And can you please make that out to Bernadette? I was taken off the joint account until I learn the value of money.
Tell me about it.
Nah, I blew my food allowance on Pokemon cards.
Kripke: Cooper?
What’s that?
I have some bad news. You’re working on a gwant pwoposal fow a new fusion weactow. I’m working on a gwant pwoposal fow a new fusion weactow. The university is only awowed to submit one pwoposal.
No, they’re making us work together.
What the fwig, Cooper? We were supposed to meet in my office a half an hour ago.
We agweed to exchange copies of our work. Let me see yours.
You think I just few off the turnip twuck? We exchange at the same time.
How do I know you’re not going to do that with mine?
Are we going to do this or not? Thank you. So, we wead each other’s work, meet again tomowow?
Nice twy. This is bwank paper.
Cough it up, Cooper.
If this one’s bwank, too, I’m going to be fuwious.
Cooper, we have a pwobwem. Your work is weawy not at a wevew I expected it to be.
Don’t pway dumb with me. We both know what your pwobwem is.
You have a girlfwiend.
So my work would suffew, too, if I was getting waid all the time.
You wucky bastard.
Okay, stop bwagging. You had some bwiwiant insights in here, but if we’re gonna make this work, you need to buckew down and focus.
Whatever. You get any wast night?
Gave it to her good, huh?
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Was she naked, or was she weawing wingewie?
How could you not notice?
Ah, you’re kiwing me, Cooper!
Sure, sure, sure. You guys ever use any toys?
A wocket? You’we a fweak! I wove it!
Amy: The monkey in my tobacco study has taken to smoking a pipe. I’m supposed to remove his brain to examine, but it’s hard because now he reminds me of my uncle. You’ve been awfully quiet tonight. Is everything okay?
All right, well, how was work today? Did you exchange your research with Kripke?
Sheldon, I wish there was something I could do to make you feel better. May I offer you a consoling hug?
Bernadette: Oh, my God. That’s so cute. I didn’t think there could be a smaller version of you.
$5,000 for a couple of dolls? Are you out of your mind?
At any point, did it dawn on you to talk to me about spending this kind of money?
I don’t believe you. Howie, we can’t afford to waste money on junk like this.
I make plenty of money. You make peanuts.
No, here’s how love works. You’re gonna return the machine, or you can print out a working set of lady parts and sleep with those. Oh, my God! Are you actually thinking about it?
Penny (under breath while hitting Leonar: Oh, my God! (Out loud) Sheldon, I know this wasn’t easy for you, and I’m really glad we could have this conversation.
